Transcript: Time Crisis Episode 2. Wow, has it been two weeks already?
2015 just keeps getting more and more Time Crisis-y.
I'm so glad that I have this outlet to talk about things and listen to music with my friends and enemies.
This is a really beautiful show.
We've got Despot, Cousin Asher, Tracy, and Heaven from Another Round Podcast,
Florence from Florence and the Machine, a music story from Rashida Jones,
and lots of great, beautiful music by wonderful people.
Time Crisis with Ezra Koenig.
What's up? This is Time Crisis with Ezra.
Got some very special guests.
We got Florence Welsh from Florence and the Machine.
What's up? Nice to see you again.
Thank you for having us.
Thank you.
We feel very privileged.
And Florence has with her, Mireille.
Hi.
You guys work together?
I'm Florence's manager. I manage her with Hannah.
Oh, it's the two of you?
Yeah.
Okay.
We're a power couple.
And as always, got my main man, Alec aka Despot.
Hi.
One thing I was thinking of when I found out that you were going to come in,
I was trying to think about the first time I ever met you.
Do you know the first time you ever met me?
I can't remember.
I think it was at a festival though, wasn't it?
This might not even be the first time I met you,
but this is the first time ever I saw your face.
Yeah.
I think.
And actually, I want you to tell me if this is true.
I think it was at Reading/Leeds.
Yes.
2008, and you were hanging out with MGMT.
When me and Andrew were sitting underneath your table that had your snacks on it
and shooting juice cartons through the paper.
Okay, I didn't even know about that.
[laughter]
Okay, so that was that summer?
I don't think, because we were hiding in your dressing room
and I think we were going to try and surprise you.
We were hiding underneath your--
Surprise me or punk me?
I don't know, but I remember we were hiding underneath the table
that had all your dressing room snacks on it
and we were using my beanie cartons to shoot as weapons or something.
And then we found some tires to play with.
So this is 2000--
Were you guys messed up?
Yes.
Okay, it's a festival, no shame in that.
So this is 2008.
Was Florence and the Machine a band then?
Yeah, we were, yeah.
But you hadn't released an album.
No, that was when my dad was tour managing us in the camper van
and we were supporting MGMT on their first European tour.
Oh.
And Reading was somewhere in the middle of that, but we had a small--
Oh, so you played. You weren't just hanging out.
No, we did play. Yeah, yeah, yeah, we played.
Yeah, I probably just didn't know about Florence and the Machine yet.
Yeah.
Because your first album came out in 2009.
I think so, yeah.
Maré, can we get a fact check on that?
The album was out in 2009, yeah.
Knew it.

- Okay, so this is 2008, leading up to your debut album.
You're touring with MGMT, whose album was out.
- Yeah.
- Big fat hits at the time.
- "Riding High."
You know them, right, Alec?
- I know them well.
- Yeah, "Electric Feel" era.
I think that's the first time I saw you,
'cause I feel like there was somebody--
- Was I wearing a clown suit?
- I feel like you were wearing some kind of like--
- I've got some really weird Polaroids of me and Andrew
both like pushing tires that we'd found.
- In clown suits.
- Around, we were both in clown suits.
- Did you have a different aesthetic back then?
Were you electro clash?
- It wasn't electro clash, it was just pretty much--
- Wait, wait, no, what do you call the clacks
on people call them?
- Oh, New Rave.
- Oh, were you New Rave a little bit?
- No, I wasn't.
Well, we weren't New Rave, no.
It was much more about--
It was much more just like if someone gave us--
Well, we'd get paid for a gig, which would be like 10 pounds,
and then you would spend it on a charity shop dress
or something.
- MGMT would only give you 10 pounds?
- Well, I think we got about--
How much money did we get?
- 50 pounds.
- 50 pounds a gig, and then we'd split it between--
- Okay, I'm gonna follow up with MGMT about this
in the next episode.
- We'd get about 50 pounds a gig,
and then we'd split it, and some money would go on
bits and bobs from charity shops and goodwill,
and then you'd stitch together an outfit from that,
and then you'd just get drunk and throw yourself
off the stage, so I don't know what scene that is,
but that's like--
You know, somewhere along the line,
you'd be covered in glitter and paint as well.
- If I try to visualize the scene of you and Andrew
walking around at Reading or Leeds 2008,
I picture you wearing some flowy--
- I think, well, at the time we had--
- You might have been wearing a cape?
- It was my--
- Or a caftan?
- Yeah, it was definitely like a cape or a clown suit,
or one of those things, because I think the festival
we were--
Tabitha had all these--
Tabitha, you know, Tabs, who does all the artwork
and helps me with the visuals,
she had this old--
I think it's from the '20s, this '20s clown suit
that I put on at a festival,
and then that became, like, for the first video
and everything, we just did it all in that clown suit.
Just sort of--
It was born at a festival.

- You're listening to "Time Crisis"
with Ezra Koenig on Beats 1.
- Today we have a very special guest, Florence,
of "Florence and the Machine,"
and her day one manager, Mare,
talking about mid-2000s London.
[laughs]
So you lived in-- you're from London, right?
- Yeah. - So for me,
this is, like, a very important period in my life, too,
is when Vampire Weekend first signed to XL,
which is based in London. - Yeah.
- So we started coming to London in 2007.
- So 2007, 2008, 2009 to me is, like, this time when
I was in London a lot, I'm starting to, like, learn
about British people and things like this,
and I've only been told this later,
that that period of time, London-based indie music
is called Thamesbeat.
- Yes, well, there was, like, a whole, like--
when I was, like, starting-- 'cause I grew up in London,
and, um, I grew up in Camberwell,
and there's a big art college in Camberwell,
and there were a lot of, like, sort of art college punk bands
that came from there, and one of them was Ludes,
and at that same time-- so they were doing--
- Wait, it's, like, Ludes like Quaaludes?
- Yeah, yeah, they're called Ludes,
and, um, my first boyfriend was in that band,
and so I kind of, like, got introduced to this--
- I didn't know you dated a Lude.
- I did, I did. - Had any of them ever
actually done Quaaludes? 'Cause those are pretty much
impossible to learn. - I don't think they had.
I don't think they had. But, um, but--
so--and then also-- so there was, like,
all these squat parties going on,
and, like, a Wow Wow art collective was happening,
but at the same time, there was, like, artists
like Jack Pignatte, Jamie T.
- Okay, so Jack Pignatte-- I know him the best, I think.
- Yeah, yeah. - 'Cause he was on Excel,
and I remember the first time I came to London with the band,
and I saw everybody was wearing kind of, like,
plaid shirts with the top button button.
- Yeah. - Did he start that?
- He did, he did. - So Jack Pignatte's
an iconic figure in mid-2000s London fashion.
- It's huge. - And--
- If you had-- - And he's also a lovely guy, obviously.
- If you rolled up your trousers,
like, a little bit at the bottoms, like, tightly,
and then you had, like, those-- I think it was those, like--
those are, like, boat shoes or Reebok classics,
and you had your shirt buttoned all the way up
to the top of the chain, that was, like, Jack.
Very stylish man. Jack--Jack started that.
- Oh, yeah, he's a very handsome, stylish person.
- But, yeah, I was watching him--
'cause we went to the same school as well.
- Wait, and this is that school that, like, everybody went to?
- Alleyne's, yeah. - And Adele went there?
- No, no, no. - Wait, no, what school am I thinking of?
- That's the Brit school. - And that's, like,
the XX? - The XX didn't go to the Brit school,
I don't think. Adele went there, went to the Brit school.
Amy Winehouse went to the Brit school.
- Okay. - Um, I went to Alleyne's,
which also Jack went to, and, uh,
some of the MacBees went to Alleyne's.
So there was, like, a-- there was, like,
a Jesse Ware went to Alleyne's. - And you guys were all there--
so you guys were all, like, in, uh, chemistry together?
- They were a couple of years above me, actually.
I was always-- I was always quite, like--
me and Jack would end up in musicals.
And he would be cast as, like, the hooker,
and he would be the drunk guy.
So, you know. [laughter]
[upbeat music]
- I feel like also, like, in the U.K.,
people get started earlier. - Yeah, well, 'cause--
- Like, people get signed to record deals when they're 16.
- Well, 'cause what you can do. - People, like, promoting parties
when they're 16. - Well, yeah, 'cause, like,
there's just so many, like-- in London,
what's really exciting-- like, how they started a whole scene.
So there was, like, the Mystery Depths, there was Ludes,
there was Jamie T, and then there was, like, the Kooks.
And so what would happen is--
- Everybody you're naming is technically Thames Beat.
- I think-- I think so.
- Can we get a confirm on that, Mariah?
- Yeah. - Okay.
This is all Thames Beat. Got it.
- And then, um-- and then, so--
but everyone was putting on, like, nights,
and so there would be a Kooks gig,
and then Kid Harpoon, he was a really big part of Thames Beat.
- Oh, yeah, also on XL. - Yes.
And there was this kind of, like, watery, piratey, like, thing
going on, and there was all these gigs happening,
and there would be, like, a big gig at Nambuka,
so the Kooks would play at Nambuka,
and then there would be an after-party at the pub behind
where Jamie T would play, and there'd be an open mic,
and I would be, like, drunk and singing on the open mic,
and so there was just this whole, like--
I think I then spent a really long time chatting to someone
while sitting on a bag of onions.
- That's an open mic. - Wasn't that your first--
No, it was the first time you sang "Kiss With A Fist"?
- That was the first time I sang "Kiss With A Fist,"
and I was really inspired by all this kind of, like--
so all of my first songs were sort of inspired
by those, like, bluesy, sort of folky things,
so, like, "Kiss With A Fist," "My Boy Boards Coffins,"
"Girl With One Eye," which is on the first record.
- Right, that really sounds, like, a little punkier.
- Yeah, yeah, yeah, yeah, and, like, "Girl With One Eye"
is a lewd song, and we covered it.
- Okay, so all this stuff that people call Thames Beat,
do you think there's some kind of, like, stylistic unity?
Or this is just, like, people who went to school together
who lived in London who are making music.
Is there an umbrella, like, style?
- I think it wasn't-- it was almost like--
it was quite visceral.
Like, it was like-- there was something quite, like,
raw about it, I think, and a lot of it was--
I don't know, like, it was sort of--
Thames is the right word, 'cause it seemed to have
so much of, like, the river in it,
and, like, there was this kind of, like, idea of, like--
it just felt like lots of, like, washed-up pirates
all making music.
- And you're well-known for loving water imagery.
- Yeah, so I think there was--
- Is it possible you're the only person who really took
the Thames Beat water vibe to heart?
- Maybe. - And really took it to the top?
- Maybe. There was just a really--
especially when I met Maree, there was a really big scene
for, like, live music and people putting on club nights
and bands playing. - And there's some--
Thames Beat was definitely not, like, electronic.
- So it's quite ramshackle. No, it wasn't.
It wasn't electronic. It was all, like--
- So is Mumford Thames Beat?
- Maree's shaking her head no. - No.
- No, they were after-- - They were after, yeah.
- It's very collaborative. - Yeah.
- Everybody just kind of-- you put on these parties.
Everyone just got involved together
and just inspired each other, really.
- It was ramshackled and, like, boozy and sort of loose
and, you know, really British.
- And nobody had that care in the world.
- Yeah. - Right.
- They just had no agenda, just doing it for the love of music.
No plan. Nobody had a plan.
- Yeah, no, definitely no plan.
- It sounds like it was just people having fun,
chilling, making music, being friends.
- Yeah.
- When's the golden age of Thames Beat?
Is it, like, 2007?
- I'd say from, yeah, 2006, '07, '08 was the heyday.
- Okay, so then my next question is,
what destroyed Thames Beat?
- I want to know who coined the term.
Like, who decided to call it Thames Beat?
- Yeah, that's a good question.
- I feel like it might have been Kais.
- Maybe it was Kais. - Maybe it was Kais.
We're gonna get Kais on the phone to break all this down shortly.
- Kais always talks about having a Thames Beat reunion,
which would be like,
"But we're still trying to get 'Ludes' back together."

This is Time Crisis with Ezra Koenig.
So who from Thames Beat is still around today?
Is Adele Thames Beat?
Kind of, yeah.
It's like South London.
It was very South London.
Are you sure Mumford & Sons are not Thames Beat?
I think they came later.
People who don't know, Kyas runs Young Turks Records,
manages the XX, an iconic figure in the London music scene.
Kyas has this bit that he does where he says that Thames Beat
is one of the best-selling waves of British music of all time
because if you add up Adele, Florence, Mumford & Sons,
you know, it's bigger than punk.
[laughter]
We'll take it.
But I remember--
But nobody's heard of it.
But the thing is I remember a club night because, again,
it was all from people like Marie, Tom Frog.
It was just like you would just put on your friends' bands
and there was one club night where it was Kate Nash
was headlining.
Kate Nash was Thames Beat?
Yeah, Kate Nash was headlining and then it was Adele
and then it was--
Kid Harpoon.
Kid Harpoon and me and that was the line-up.
It was a night at the Lock Tavern in Camden.
Kyas has still got the flyer for it.
Okay, so that's a legendary night.
Me and Kid Harpoon were doing a lot of writing together.
You still write with him?
Yeah, yeah, yeah, yeah.
We wrote a lot of--
Yeah, yeah, yeah.
You wrote on the last album?
Yeah, yeah, yeah, yeah.
But I would watch Kid Harpoon play and I just--
watching like Ludes, Kid Harpoon, watching those guys--
like Dave Ashby was the lead singer of Ludes
and he's the most amazing performer still--
and watching those guys perform with some of my--
and Jamie, those were my first big influences in performance.
Yeah.
What's up with Jamie T now?
He just released another record.
It's really amazing actually.
Yeah.
And Jack, yeah, watching Jack, it was like--
there was so much energy to it, like it was a real like--
it was just an energetic time.
Yeah.
Wait, so I'll ask one more time.
What killed Thames Beat?
It's sort of--
What destroyed Thames Beat?
Every golden age has its downfall.
I think if you have like that--
the thing is like if it is that much ramshackle
and then it is like-- it's hard to keep it up.
Do you know what I mean?
What sounds like it was also very youthful.
Yeah, yeah.
Everybody just aged out.
And also because there's no agenda.
Do you know what I mean?
It's just like-- it just does what it does.
Right.
It was a shooting star.
Yeah.
Everybody at that time, everyone was kind of on the same level.
Yeah.
I suppose it kind of changed as people got more successful.
I guess it couldn't stay as crazy as it was.
Adele started coming through with in-ears.
[laughter]
And it's-- the vibe is totally different now.
So Adele killed Thames Beat is what you're--
No!
Adele killed Thames Beat, but she gave birth to so many other things.
That's life, right?
Thames Beat died so that Adele could live
and become the best-selling British artist of all time,
which is amazing, which I think is dope.
Is that right?
Her second album is the best-selling British album of all time?
Probably.
I reckon.
And it's on an independent label.
That's amazing.
Yeah.
So--
Oh, I didn't know that.
Yeah, it's on XL.
No, I mean I didn't know best-selling.
I know it's on XL.
It's definitely top ten.
Definitely sold a lot of records.
Yeah.
[laughter]
Like she beat the Beatles?
I think she beat the Beatles, yeah.
Yeah, yeah.
She did.
That's crazy.
Beatles are trash.
They're on a major label.
First of all, Beatles are trash.
You heard it here first.
I still listen to Rolling in the Deep regularly.
It's a great song.
I listen to the Jamie XX remix quite frequently.
And it's just one of those songs where you're like,
"Oh, God, I wish I'd written that.
It's so good."
It's like one of those songs where you're like,
"This is just amazing."
It's an instant classic.
Yeah.

No, but I'm saying, I think even if Thames Beat
was this kind of like ramshackle thing,
I think it's great that people came out of a scene like that
and did big things.
Well, 'cause there was also, like, there was Thames Beat
and then there was, like, what Adele and, like,
I started singing a lot at was this sort of--
there was, like, a London folk scene that was really--
Wait, so now does that count Mumford?
I think so, yes.
Maybe.
I think what happens is, like, there was Thames Beat
and then it kind of, like, on the other side
there was, like, the Blue Flowers nights, like,
with the London folk scene with Johnny Flynn,
Laura Marling.
How does Noah and the Whale fit in?
Noah and the Whale was in there, so, like, Jack and, like,
I was sort of--
Oh, so it sounds like Mumford killed Thames Beat.
[laughter]
No, but that's, like, you know, that's like in America
in the '80s, you had all the hair metal
and then Kurt Cobain comes through and says,
"Enough of that."
[laughter]
It wasn't Marcus, Laura Marling's guitarist.
Yes, yeah, yeah, yeah, yeah, yeah.
So there was, like, the London folk scene
and I think Mumford and I was doing gigs there,
a bit in there, and you put on a folk--
a "Folk It Up," "Folking It Up."
"Folking It Up."
Was that a night?
That was, like, one of the first times I met Maraid
was going to the "Folking It Up" club night
and you were wearing a gold cape, actually.
A gold cape.
Jack played that.
He dipped a toe in both scenes.
Yeah, he was in the folk scene and the--
So I started doing gigs at a lot of the folk nights.
I definitely thought you were a folk singer at the beginning.
Yeah.
'Cause your vibe could kind of hang with both
the folkies and the Thames Beat.
Yeah, depending on how drunk I was.
Right.
I don't know.
Well, look, these two scenes together,
this mid-2000s London folk scene and Thames Beat
have produced a lot of big, important music.
Yeah, but what's so nice is actually when you do think about it,
it did all come from small live gigs, which is really, like--
I remember seeing Adele at that night
and you just knew it was something so special.
Like, seeing it in that tiny room,
and she just sung with the guitar,
and I remember just going, "Oh, my God."
So, you know, seeing it up that close and so early on,
you already knew that it was something really, really incredible.
Yeah.
All right, so if you had to pick one song
to really sum up mid-2000s Thames Beat,
what do you think is your iconic Thames Beat song?
It's probably Jamie T. Sheila, I think.
We think--
Or--
"Happy as Annie," "Larrick in Love."
Yeah, "Happy as Annie," "Larrick in Love."
And also, like, Tom Beard, who's taken all of my cover photos
and done all that, he was, like, best friends with "Larrick in Love."
And he was, like, 15.
Yeah, he was, like, 15, and that's how we all met.
Like, that's how I met him in the first photo.
And was he taking pictures of all this?
Yeah, yeah, yeah.
So when's the Thames Beat Rizzoli coffee table book going to drop?
He's got all of them, and he could make a Tom Beard--
Did you get on that?
Yeah, he could make a whole Thames--
Tom Beard, TB, Thames Beat, Tom Beard, Thames Beat.

because there was almost like a directness

you know, it was like songs.
